title: Sue Day
text:
Susan Margaret Day (born 29 October 1972) is an <a href="England">English</a> <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who played <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%2315.%20Fullback">fullback</a> for <a href="Wasps%20RFC">London Wasps Ladies</a> and for <a href="England%20national%20women%27s%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>. Sue played in three <a href="Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">Rugby World Cups</a> and is England's top try scorer with 61 tries in 59 caps.
She was appointed <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Member of the Order of the British Empire</a> (MBE) in the <a href="2020%20Birthday%20Honours">2020 Birthday Honours</a> for services to gender equality in sport.
Career.
Day made her debut versus in 1997. She was selected for the <a href="2006%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2006 Six Nations</a> Squad. She appeared again for the <a href="2007%20Six%20Nations%20Championship">2007 Six Nations</a> opener. She can play on the wing, in the centre or at fullback. She competed at the <a href="1998%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">1998 Women's Rugby World Cup</a>, and <a href="2002%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2002 Women's Rugby World Cup</a> finishing second.
Sue or 'Daisy' as she is known to her teammates is the top try scorer in IRB world cups, with 19 tries. After retiring from 15's, Sue returned to the international game, captaining <a href="Simon%20Amor">Simon Amor</a> and <a href="Mike%20Friday">Mike Friday</a>'s <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team%20%28sevens%29">7's squad</a> to the <a href="2009%20Rugby%20World%20Cup%20Sevens">7's world cup</a> in March 2009.
In 2013 Day became the first female president of <a href="Wasps%20FC">Wasps FC</a> in their 146-year history. She is England RFU Chief Financial Officer.
